title: New Classes/Subclasses List

embed.description: Hey all, It's been a bit since we've reexamined our Class and Subclass structure, and as expected our understandings of it have evolved a bit over the past year. Let's jump into the the key insights we've had during this time.

So why is Nocturne considered an assassin?  He has no escapes.

As a nocturne main (who would of thought right?) I think an escape might make him OP. As a burst assassin he does quite well(in talking warriors,PD,deaths dance,IE) he is a deep diver with (imo) the best engage in game. Oracles into an R on a carry has won me too many games. I'm sitting at 70% winrate on him and as far as escapes go for him, I make very liberal use of flash and guardian angel. GA is not an escape I know but I'll dive in blow up a carry and hope my team can last long enough for me to be back up

> I know but I'll dive in blow up a carry and hope my team can last long enough for me to be back up. 

See that just screams diver to me.
So Nocturne is an Assassin and Ahri isn't? Bulllllshit.
Might be that those are the subclasses Riot would _want_ them to be; like how currently Evelynn _should_ be an Assassin but in reality is played like a Diver.

There's a bit of that going on yeah. Nocturne's not exactly an assassin at present, though when we do see him effective it's generally with a really bursty assassin like build. Long term we expect he'll move more in that direction as a result.

Ahri's certainly got assassin qualities, some of that's that there's pretty significant overlap between Burst Mages and Assassins though, with both trying to kill specific targets quickly. Adding mobility to a burst mage gets them pretty close to an assassin generally as a result (Ahri/LB/Lissandra all having some degree of assassin style flank/pick potential).

Evelynn's update should make an assassin playstyle much more sensible on her (less build tanky and grind people down diver style required).
While you're here, do you have a rough opinion on what champions currently has this kind of mismatch between intended- and in-practice-subclass? What others are there?
Evelynn and Fizz (when bruiser build dominates) are the two that leap out for me.
Would you mind elaborating on Skarner as well? Last I remember, he was supposed to move more into the direction of Tank-Vanguard...

Looking at Skarner at present we concluded he was playing much closer to Jarvan, Vi etc - fighters with some initiation capability who are still pretty focused on a particular target, rather than team initiation as a whole. His builds and playstyle match that, with a mixture of damage and defense. Can still see some arguments for making him Vanguard like, that's a could happen rather than something we're confident will happen though, in contrast with Evelynn. Nocturne's a best guess situation, overall we figured Assassin was the better description than Diver however.

Yes on Renekton (still a Diver).

Quick Question on this is he (Skarner) still slated for a future rework? And second from what you are saying here is that you are classifying him as such due to current build/style and not intended, correct or is that to change if he receives changes?

We think Skarner would benefit from changes larger than just balance ones. We don't have a rework currently on the books for him however. We are classifying him based off his current state as a result, since we don't have a clear enough expectation he'll change.

Edit: Oh, uniques wise our feeling was that trying to push them into other categories resulted in less clear definitions for those categories if they were only rough fits and didn't really describe them accurately enough. Can certainly say that Azir has marksmen like elements for example, but it's not very representative.
Why azir is not a battle mage ? Even if I think it's messy, I imagined that battle mage were the counterpart (all in one, ranged and melee) of marksmen and skirmishers for AP.

Why is {{champion:163}} a battle mage and {{champion:127}} a burst mage?  I feel like they should be swapped since battle mages thrive in close quarters and have ways of staying there, which Liss' kit does well with W and R.  Burst mages want to stay a bit further away and pick off a single target, which Taliyah's kit does well with W+E combo.

Taliyah - Meaningful sustained damage output, especially once Q is max rank. 

Lissandra - Longer CDs, and dependent on her ult for kill pressure usually, so less of a sustained output. 

Taliyah's certainly got some burst elements, W pick potential especially, and Lissandra does have some tools to be closer to the fight battle mage style. Overall though those were the categories we felt best fit their playstyles.

>Taliyah - Meaningful sustained damage output, especially once Q is max rank.

Then why is Zyra a catcher? She has a very similar pattern to Taliyah in terms of everything, she's a high damage output/distruption threat just like Taliyah.

For Meddler (if he sees this)

I'm noticing you mentioned Eve {{champion:28}}  being in the Assassin category because that's where her VGU is going to lead her, but Urgot {{champion:6}} however is still in the Unique category. Is this categorization for Urgot  just for his pre-VGU, or are you aiming to keep him Unique post-VGU. Not to delve too deep in of course. I understand if you can't say anything regarding him, I was just curious. Thanks!
That's reflective of Urgot's current kit. Might or might not still be in the unique category post update (we're pretty sure as to the answer, but it's too early to talk about his kit).
Will this be updated in the client as well?

Unlikely. We talk about these definitions for anyone interested in understanding how we think about the different types of champion, it's not something that really drives champion selection or anything in game though.
I'd like it just from an organization point of view. Fighters list is huge in champ select.

What makes {{champion:111}} a Vanguard and not a Catcher?
On that note, who had the final say in {{champion:12}} being a Vanguard instead of a Warden? That is a hard toss up.

Big distinction between Vanguards and Catchers is that Vanguards go in with their initiation and then tank a bunch of damage. Catchers more often fish for picks from a safer spots further away (Rakan's a bit of an odd one there, though his ability to get out via E fairly reliably still gives a pseudo ranged fishing pattern).

Alistar wise power of the WQ combo was the key argument. He can peel, no argument, but he's always been scary to play against because of his ability to get onto and CC enemies aggressively.

{{champion:111}}  is a lot tankier, has more initiation potential, and has more CC.

I'm **guessing** {{champion:12}} 's new E finally pushed him into being a Vanguard first, Warden second. He has a lot of peeling potential, but his new E encourages him to stay in the middle of a fight instead of just getting enemies off his teammates.

Honestly, Mordekaiser would fall more into a Hybrid category between Juggernaut and Battlemage in my opinion.
